title: Modeling a Periodic Context - Hour Hand of Clock

content.question: Part A The graph of <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> and its dashed midline for two full cycles is shown. Five points, <math alttext="F"><mi>F</mi></math>, <math alttext="G"><mi>G</mi></math>, <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math>, <math alttext="K"><mi>K</mi></math>, and <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math>, are labeled on the graph. No scale is indicated, and no axes are presented. Determine possible coordinates <math alttext="open parentheses t comma h open parentheses t close parentheses close parentheses"><mfenced><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>h</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></math> for the five points: <math alttext="F"><mi>F</mi></math>, <math alttext="G"><mi>G</mi></math>, <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math>, <math alttext="K"><mi>K</mi></math>, and <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math>. Moving from left to right: Point F is at a maximum point. Point G is on the midline. Point J is at a minimum point. Point K is on the midline. Point P is at a maximum point. The center of the clockface is represented by a small circle. Extending from the center are two hands that point to numbers on the clock. One of the hands is labeled Hour Hand. The clockwise rotation direction for the Hour Hand is indicated. Numbers on the clock are located near the clock’s perimeter. The numbers divide the clock into 12 sectors or sections. The number directly above the center is 12. Moving from the 12 to the right in a clockwise direction, the numbers appear as follows. 1 2 3, which is directly to the right of the center 4 5 6, which is directly below the center 7 8 9, which is directly to the left of the center 10 11 and back to 12 Note that the figure is not drawn to scale.
